name: Dataset
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset
description:
Dataset

Represents a Dataset. A dataset is a grouping mechanism that holds zero or more tables. Datasets are the lowest level unit of access control; you cannot control access at the table level. A dataset is contained within a specific project.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.create_dataset "my_dataset",
                                  name: "My Dataset",
                                  description: "This is my Dataset"

methods.name: dataset_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#dataset_id
methods.description: A unique ID for this dataset, without the project name. The ID must contain only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum length is 1,024 characters.

methods.name: project_id
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#project_id
methods.description: The ID of the project containing this dataset.

methods.name: name
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#name
methods.description: A descriptive name for the dataset.

methods.name: name=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#name=
methods.description: Updates the descriptive name for the dataset.

methods.name: etag
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#etag
methods.description: A string hash of the dataset.

methods.name: api_url
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#api_url
methods.description: A URL that can be used to access the dataset using the REST API.

methods.name: description
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#description
methods.description: A user-friendly description of the dataset.

methods.name: description=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#description=
methods.description: Updates the user-friendly description of the dataset.

methods.name: default_expiration
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#default_expiration
methods.description: The default lifetime of all tables in the dataset, in milliseconds.

methods.name: default_expiration=
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#default_expiration=
methods.description: Updates the default lifetime of all tables in the dataset, in milliseconds.

methods.name: created_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#created_at
methods.description: The time when this dataset was created.

methods.name: modified_at
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#modified_at
methods.description: The date when this dataset or any of its tables was last modified.

methods.name: location
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#location
methods.description: The geographic location where the dataset should reside. Possible values include EU and US. The default value is US.

methods.name: access
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#access
methods.description: Retrieves the access rules for a Dataset. The rules can be updated when passing a block, see Dataset::Access for all the methods available.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

dataset.access # [{"role"=>"OWNER",
               #   "specialGroup"=>"projectOwners"},
               #  {"role"=>"WRITER",
               #   "specialGroup"=>"projectWriters"},
               #  {"role"=>"READER",
               #   "specialGroup"=>"projectReaders"},
               #  {"role"=>"OWNER",
               #   "userByEmail"=>"123456789-...com"}]

examples.caption: Manage the access rules by passing a block:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

dataset.access do |access|
  access.add_owner_group "owners@example.com"
  access.add_writer_user "writer@example.com"
  access.remove_writer_user "readers@example.com"
  access.add_reader_special :all
  access.add_reader_view other_dataset_view_object
end

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting rules

params.name: yield.access
params.description: the object accepting rules

methods.name: delete
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#delete
methods.description: Permanently deletes the dataset. The dataset must be empty before it can be deleted unless the force option is set to true.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
dataset.delete

params.name: force
params.description: If true, delete all the tables in the dataset. If false and the dataset contains tables, the request will fail. Default is false.

returns.description: Returns true if the dataset was deleted.

methods.name: create_table
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#create_table
methods.description: Creates a new table. If you are adapting existing code that was written for the Rest API , you can pass the table’s schema as a hash (see example.)

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table"

examples.caption: You can also pass name and description options.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table",
                             name: "My Table",
                             description: "A description of table."

examples.caption: Or the table’s schema can be configured with the block.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"

table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |t|
  t.schema.string "first_name", mode: :required
  t.schema.record "cities_lived", mode: :required do |s|
    s.string "place", mode: :required
    s.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
  end
end

examples.caption: You can define the schema using a nested block.
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.create_table "my_table" do |t|
  t.name = "My Table",
  t.description = "A description of my table."
  t.schema do |s|
    s.string "first_name", mode: :required
    s.record "cities_lived", mode: :repeated do |r|
      r.string "place", mode: :required
      r.integer "number_of_years", mode: :required
    end
  end
end

params.name: table_id
params.description:
The ID of the table. The ID must contain only
letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), or underscores (_). The maximum
length is 1,024 characters.

params.name: name
params.description: A descriptive name for the table.

params.name: description
params.description: A user-friendly description of the table.

params.name: yield
params.description: a block for setting the table

params.name: yield.table
params.description: the table object to be updated

methods.name: create_view
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#create_view
methods.description: Creates a new view table from the given query.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
view = dataset.create_view "my_view",
          "SELECT name, age FROM proj.dataset.users"

examples.caption: A name and description can be provided:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
view = dataset.create_view "my_view",
          "SELECT name, age FROM proj.dataset.users",
          name: "My View", description: "This is my view"

params.name: table_id
params.description:
The ID of the view table. The ID must contain
only letters (a-z, A-Z), numbers (0-9), or underscores (_). The
maximum length is 1,024 characters.

params.name: query
params.description:
The query that BigQuery executes when the view
is referenced.

params.name: name
params.description: A descriptive name for the table.

params.name: description
params.description: A user-friendly description of the table.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is false.

methods.name: table
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#table
methods.description: Retrieves an existing table by ID.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
table = dataset.table "my_table"
puts table.name

params.name: table_id
params.description: The ID of a table.

returns.description: Returns nil if the table does not exist

methods.name: tables
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#tables
methods.description: Retrieves the list of tables belonging to the dataset.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
tables = dataset.tables
tables.each do |table|
  puts table.name
end

examples.caption: Retrieve all tables: (See Table::List#all)
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new
dataset = bigquery.dataset "my_dataset"
tables = dataset.tables
tables.all do |table|
  puts table.name
end

params.name: token
params.description:
A previously-returned page token representing
part of the larger set of results to view.

params.name: max
params.description: Maximum number of tables to return.

methods.name: query_job
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#query_job
methods.description:
Queries data using the asynchronous method.

Sets the current dataset as the default dataset in the query. Useful for using unqualified table names.

When using standard SQL and passing arguments using params, Ruby types are mapped to BigQuery types as follows:

BigQuery Ruby Notes
BOOL true/false  
INT64 Integer  
FLOAT64 Float  
STRING STRING  
DATETIME DateTime DATETIME does not support time zone.
DATE Date  
TIMESTAMP Time  
TIME Google::Cloud::BigQuery::Time  
BYTES File, IO, StringIO, or similar  
ARRAY Array Nested arrays, nil values are not supported.
STRUCT Hash Hash keys may be strings or symbols.

See Data Types for an overview of each BigQuery data type, including allowed values.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM my_table"

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row["name"]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using legacy SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM my_table",
                         legacy_sql: true

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row["name"]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using positional query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM my_table WHERE id = ?",
                         params: [1]

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row["name"]
  end
end

examples.caption: Query using named query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

job = bigquery.query_job "SELECT name FROM my_table WHERE id = @id",
                         params: { id: 1 }

job.wait_until_done!
if !job.failed?
  job.query_results.each do |row|
    puts row["name"]
  end
end

params.name: query
params.description: A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute. Example: “SELECT count(f1) FROM [myProjectId:myDatasetId.myTableId]”.

params.name: params
params.description: Standard SQL only. Used to pass query arguments when the query string contains either positional (?) or named (@myparam) query parameters. If value passed is an array ["foo"], the query must use positional query parameters. If value passed is a hash { myparam: "foo" }, the query must use named query parameters. When set, legacy_sql will automatically be set to false and standard_sql to true.

params.name: priority
params.description: Specifies a priority for the query. Possible values include INTERACTIVE and BATCH. The default value is INTERACTIVE.

params.name: cache
params.description: Whether to look for the result in the query cache. The query cache is a best-effort cache that will be flushed whenever tables in the query are modified. The default value is true. For more information, see query caching.

params.name: table
params.description:
The destination table where the query results
should be stored. If not present, a new table will be created to
store the results.

params.name: create
params.description:
Specifies whether the job is allowed to create new tables.

The following values are supported:

  • needed - Create the table if it does not exist.
  • never - The table must already exist. A ‘notFound’ error is raised if the table does not exist.

params.name: write
params.description:
Specifies the action that occurs if the destination table already exists.

The following values are supported:

  • truncate - BigQuery overwrites the table data.
  • append - BigQuery appends the data to the table.
  • empty - A ‘duplicate’ error is returned in the job result if the table exists and contains data.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect for this query. If set to true, the query will use standard SQL rather than the legacy SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect for this query. If set to false, the query will use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect. Optional. The default value is false.

params.name: large_results
params.description: This option is specific to Legacy SQL. If true, allows the query to produce arbitrarily large result tables at a slight cost in performance. Requires table parameter to be set.

params.name: flatten
params.description: This option is specific to Legacy SQL. Flattens all nested and repeated fields in the query results. The default value is true. large_results parameter must be true if this is set to false.

methods.name: query
title: Google
Cloud
Bigquery
Dataset#query
methods.description:
Queries data using the synchronous method.

Sets the current dataset as the default dataset in the query. Useful for using unqualified table names.

When using standard SQL and passing arguments using params, Ruby types are mapped to BigQuery types as follows:

BigQuery Ruby Notes
BOOL true/false  
INT64 Integer  
FLOAT64 Float  
STRING STRING  
DATETIME DateTime DATETIME does not support time zone.
DATE Date  
TIMESTAMP Time  
TIME Google::Cloud::BigQuery::Time  
BYTES File, IO, StringIO, or similar  
ARRAY Array Nested arrays, nil values are not supported.
STRUCT Hash Hash keys may be strings or symbols.

See Data Types for an overview of each BigQuery data type, including allowed values.

examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM my_table"

data.each do |row|
  puts row["name"]
end

examples.caption: Query using legacy SQL:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM my_table",
                      legacy_sql: true

data.each do |row|
  puts row["name"]
end

examples.caption: Query using positional query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM my_table WHERE id = ?",
                      params: [1]

data.each do |row|
  puts row["name"]
end

examples.caption: Query using named query parameters:
examples.code:
require "google/cloud/bigquery"

bigquery = Google::Cloud::Bigquery.new

data = bigquery.query "SELECT name FROM my_table WHERE id = @id",
                      params: { id: 1 }

data.each do |row|
  puts row["name"]
end

params.name: query
params.description: A query string, following the BigQuery query syntax, of the query to execute. Example: “SELECT count(f1) FROM [myProjectId:myDatasetId.myTableId]”.

params.name: params
params.description: Standard SQL only. Used to pass query arguments when the query string contains either positional (?) or named (@myparam) query parameters. If value passed is an array ["foo"], the query must use positional query parameters. If value passed is a hash { myparam: "foo" }, the query must use named query parameters. When set, legacy_sql will automatically be set to false and standard_sql to true.

params.name: max
params.description:
The maximum number of rows of data to return per
page of results. Setting this flag to a small value such as 1000 and
then paging through results might improve reliability when the query
result set is large. In addition to this limit, responses are also
limited to 10 MB. By default, there is no maximum row count, and
only the byte limit applies.

params.name: timeout
params.description:
How long to wait for the query to complete,
in milliseconds, before the request times out and returns. Note that
this is only a timeout for the request, not the query. If the query
takes longer to run than the timeout value, the call returns without
any results and with QueryData#complete? set to false. The default
value is 10000 milliseconds (10 seconds).

params.name: dryrun
params.description: If set to true, BigQuery doesn’t run the job. Instead, if the query is valid, BigQuery returns statistics about the job such as how many bytes would be processed. If the query is invalid, an error returns. The default value is false.

params.name: cache
params.description: Whether to look for the result in the query cache. The query cache is a best-effort cache that will be flushed whenever tables in the query are modified. The default value is true. For more information, see query caching.

params.name: standard_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s standard SQL dialect for this query. If set to true, the query will use standard SQL rather than the legacy SQL dialect. When set to true, the values of large_results and flatten are ignored; the query will be run as if large_results is true and flatten is false. Optional. The default value is true.

params.name: legacy_sql
params.description: Specifies whether to use BigQuery’s legacy SQL dialect for this query. If set to false, the query will use BigQuery’s standard SQL When set to false, the values of large_results and flatten are ignored; the query will be run as if large_results is true and flatten is false. Optional. The default value is false.
